<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {

 *            true = include NULL Token

 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
```
while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
    String s = st.nextToken();
    if (s.equals(delim)) {
        sb.append(" ").append(delim);
    } else {
        sb.append(s).append(delim);

            st.nextToken();

}
return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
```

}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
String type = st.nextToken();
String one = st.nextToken();
String two = st.nextToken();
String three = st.nextToken();
String four = st.nextToken();
String five = st.nextToken();

System.out.println(
"[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
}
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
}

<<<explanation>>>: The issue with the original code is that the `StringTokenizer` class in Java does not automatically handle empty fields. When you use a tab as a delimiter, the `StringTokenizer` will only consider tokens that are not empty. To handle empty fields, you can use a regular expression to split the string into tokens. Here's an example of how you can modify the `getStringTokenizerStrict` method to use a regular expression:

static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
```
while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
    String s = st.nextToken();
    if (s.equals(delim)) {
        sb.append(" ").append(delim);
    } else {
        Pattern pattern = Pattern.compile(delim + "+" + delim, Pattern.DOTALL);
        Matcher matcher = pattern.matcher(s);
        while (matcher.find()) {
            sb.append(matcher.group(0));
        }
    }
}
return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
```
}

In this modified version, we use a regular expression to split the string into tokens. The regular expression `delim + "+" + delim` matches any sequence of `delim` followed by one or more occurrences of `delim`. This will match any empty fields that are surrounded by tabs. The `DOTALL` flag makes the dot in the regular expression match all characters, including newline characters, so that it can match the end of each line.

With this modification, the `getStringTokenizerStrict` method will correctly handle empty fields in the input string.
